questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents with central field defects in the presence of a relatively normal peripheral field. Previous medical history is significant for the presence of myopia. The exam findings are shown in the images below. The gene responsible for the cases of juvenile onset variants of this disease resides on which chromosome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1 The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of glaucomatous optic neuropathy . Refractive status, as myopia carries an increased risk of POAG and hypermetropia in primary angle - closure glaucoma ( PACG ). Myopic disc with glaucoma, as seen in the first image, refers to a tilted (obliquely inserted), shallow disc with a temporal crescent of para papillary atrophy, together with features of glaucomatous damage. Optic disc haemorrhage can be seen in the second image . An optic disc haemorrhage is a risk factor for the development and progression of glaucoma and can be missed unless magnification is used to examine the disc. Pathological cupping is caused by an irreversible decrease in the number of nerve fibres, glial cells, and blood vessels. A documented increase in cup size is always significant. If an eye with a small optic disc and correspondingly small cup develops glaucoma, the cup will increase in size, but even in the presence of substantial damage. may still be smaller than that of a large physiological cup. This form of the disease is characterized by markedly elevated pressures , often >40 mm Hg, and a poor response to medication.

Highyeild:

Other cloned genes known to be associated with glaucoma include PAX6 (11p13, aniridia), CYP1B1 (2p21, congenital glaucoma), PITX2 (4q25, Axenfeld-Rieger syndrome), and LMX1B (9q34, glaucoma associated with nail-patella syndrome).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. 3 - Not the correct option. Option: C. 8 - Not the correct option. Option: D . 21 - Not the correct option because the gene responsible for this disease is present on chromosome no. 1

Extraedge:

Risk factors associated with glaucomatous opticneuropathy: Cardiovascular disease Ischaemia Diabetes Hypertension

questions.text: A 56-year-old male came in with a complaint of vision loss. Which of the following features would raise doubts about the diagnosis of glaucomatous optic nerve damage? Pallor out of proportion to cupping Markedly asymmetric colour visual loss Field defects obeying the vertical meridian Presence of an afferent pupillary defect Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

1, 2, and 3 It is important to correlate changes in the visual field with changes in the optic disc. The following should raise suspicion about the diagnosis of glaucoma : An optic disc that is less cupped than would be expected for observed field loss, A pallor of the disc that is more impressive than the cupping, Markedly asymmetric dyschromatopsia, or Visual field defects are uncharacteristic of glaucoma (e.g., respecting the vertical meridian).

Highyeild:

Damage to the optic nerve can lead to temporary or permanent vision loss. Glaucoma is the most common optic nerve disorder. If left untreated, it can lead to blindness .

questions.text: A 56-year-old man came for a regular checkup at the Ophthalmology OPD. He is non diabetic or hypertensive. Which of the following findings is incorrect regarding optic disc?

options.label: A
options.text: The normal cup to disc ratio is 3:1.

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetry of the cup to disc ratio of >0.2 is seen between both eyes in glaucoma

options.label: C
options.text: Small optic nerve head is seen in hypermetropia

options.label: D
options.text: Localized thinning of the neuroretinal rim may be observed in glaucomatous eye

questions.correct_answer: A. The normal cup to disc ratio is 3:1.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The normal cup to disc ratio is 3:1. The normal cup diameter to disc diameter ratio is 0.3:1 and not 3:1

Highyeild:

Pathogenesis of ONH changes in glaucoma Mechanical Effects: Raised IOP forces lamina cribrosa backward and squeezes nerve fibres within, disturb axoplasmic flow. Vascular Effects: Ischaemic Atrophy of Nerve Fibre.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Asymmetry of the cup:disc ratio ( > 0.2) between the two eyes is a feature of glaucoma. Option: C. In some cases of hypermetropia, a small optic nerve head can be seen with densely packed nerves. Option: D. A localized notch or thinning of the neuroretinal rim may be seen in the glaucomatous eye.

Extraedge:

Treatment Unfortunately, there is no treatment to reverse the secondary end stage glaucomatous optic atrophy . Aggressive ocular and systemic treatments are preventive measures and must be instituted in high risk individuals before atrophic progression . Preventive therapy includes topical ocular hypotensive medications.

questions.text: What are the optic disc changes seen in normal tension glaucoma?

options.label: B
options.text: Decrease in cup to disc ratio

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and C Normal - tension glaucoma is seen in about 15% of patients where an intraocular pressure of less than 21 mm Hg is recorded repeatedly with all the other features of primary open angle glaucoma. Both parapapillary atrophy and superficial disc haemorrhages are observed in glaucomatous eyes, along with other vascular signs suggestive of an acquired cupping, such as baring of the circumlinear vessels and overpass of central vessels. Option B An enlarged cup:disc ratio ( > 0.5) is observed in glaucoma, The normal cup diameter to disc diameter ratio is 0 . 3:1 .

Highyeild:

If Glaucoma left untreated can progress from gradual vision loss to total permanent blindness .

questions.text: A patient aged 45 years presents to the emergency department with redness in the right eye since 1 hour. He also complains of headache and diminution of vision. On examination, there is a vertically oval, mid-dilated pupil, and on fundoscopy, the optic disc is hyperaemic with a cup disc-ratio of 0.6. What is the appropriate treatment for this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iv acetazolamide This is a case of acute angle closure glaucoma . Treatment must be started promptly with IV acetazolamide or IV mannitol to lower the IOP, followed by topical pilocarpine 2% to constrict the pupil and pull the iris away from the angle.

Highyeild:

Usually, we start with non surgical treatment; if it is not effective, we go to laser therapy and lastly, we go to surgical treatment. But in emergency cases (closed angle glaucoma), surgery is the first choice.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Hypromellose 2% is a viscoelastic used in intraocular surgeries to coat intraocular lenses and instruments during cataract extraction and intraocular lens insertion. Option: C. iv hydrocortisone is recommended in inflammatory conditions like posterior uveitis, papillitis, retrobulbar neuritis, etc. IV acetazolamide is the treatment for acute glaucoma. Option D Topical antibiotics are instilled in cases of dacrocystitis, unresolved bacterial conjunctivitis, etc. Topical antibiotics are of no use in the management of acute angle closure glaucoma.
